coredata.dc:title: Moving beyond the distinction between the bright and dark sides of termites to achieve sustainable development goals
coredata.prism:issueName: Vectors and medical and veterinary entomology • Special Section on Insects and the UN sustainable development goals
coredata.dc:creator: Jouquet, Pascal
Traoré, Saran
Harit, Ajay
Choosai, Chutinan
Cheik, Sougueh
Bottinelli, Nicolas
coredata.dc:description: Termites are amongst the main macroinvertebrate decomposers in tropical ecosystems and they exert additional impacts through the creation of biostructures (mounds, galleries, sheetings, etc.) with different soil physical and chemical properties, thereby impacting positively on numerous ecosystem services for humankind. Unfortunately, this positive or ‘bright’ role of termites is often overshadowed by their ‘dark’ side, that is, their status as pests threatening agriculture and constructions. This article assesses advances in our knowledge of the impact of termites on several sustainable development goals (SDGs 1 ‘no poverty’, 2 ‘zero hunger’, 3 ‘good health’, 9 ‘innovation’, 11 ‘sustainable cities’, 13 ‘climate action’ and 15 ‘life on land’). Finally, using the Indian myth of Valmiki as a parable, we illustrate that a reconciliation between the termite's dark and bright sides is needed if we want to reduce our dramatic impact on biodiversity and more generally achieve SDGs.

xocs:title-editors-group.ce:title: Vectors and medical and veterinary entomology • Special Section on Insects and the UN sustainable development goals

xocs:hub-sec.xocs:hub-sec-title: Special section on Insects and the UN sustainable development goals edited by Olivier Dangles and Verónica Crespo-Pérez

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Dilemma between harmful versus beneficial impacts

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Number of articles found on Web of Science (WoS) focusing on the harmful impact of termites (i.e. their pest status, in black, based on the key words: ‘termites’ and ‘pests’) and those focusing on their beneficial impacts and the ecosystem services that they can provide to humankind, with the key words ‘termites’ and either ‘ecosystem engineers’, in white, or ‘sustainable’ or ‘sustainability’, in grey). Note that the different regressions are all exponential curves.

Bibliometric map representing similarities between 71 pre-selected articles identified by WoS (i.e. reviews, book chapters and irrelevant articles were not considered in this list) and using VoS-viewer software. The articles were all carefully read, and keywords were redefined by the same person to identify similarities between studies that could not be first identified by WoS. The full list of keywords is given in the supplementary file. The size of the circle is proportional to the publication number.

Photo of an abandoned mound of Odontotermes obesus in South India (Tamil Nadu), most likely occupied by a snake. Note the presence of offerings and a statuette representing an unidentified god in front of a cavity and above the mound (colourful powders and cloths) [photograph by P. Jouquet].

Schematic representation of the impact of termites on SDGs. Termite ‘machinery’ depends upon carbon energy coming from the soil (e.g. humus) or plants (i.e. residues and/or living parts). This consumption is essential for termites to provide multiple ecosystem services. Their impacts are related to their role in the food web (e.g. their consumption by animals and their impact on the cycling of nutrients) and to bioturbation (e.g. the formation of mounds and soil pores), which all positively influence numerous SDGs. However, C consumption by termites is also necessarily associated with disservices, such as reductions in yield or C stocks in the soil.

head.ce:title: Moving beyond the distinction between the bright and dark sides of termites to achieve sustainable development goals

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Termites are amongst the main macroinvertebrate decomposers in tropical ecosystems and they exert additional impacts through the creation of biostructures (mounds, galleries, sheetings, etc.) with different soil physical and chemical properties, thereby impacting positively on numerous ecosystem services for humankind. Unfortunately, this positive or ‘bright’ role of termites is often overshadowed by their ‘dark’ side, that is, their status as pests threatening agriculture and constructions. This article assesses advances in our knowledge of the impact of termites on several sustainable development goals (SDGs 1 ‘no poverty’, 2 ‘zero hunger’, 3 ‘good health’, 9 ‘innovation’, 11 ‘sustainable cities’, 13 ‘climate action’ and 15 ‘life on land’). Finally, using the Indian myth of Valmiki as a parable, we illustrate that a reconciliation between the termite's dark and bright sides is needed if we want to reduce our dramatic impact on biodiversity and more generally achieve SDGs.

ce:sections.ce:para: This review comes from a themed issue on Special section on insects
Edited by Olivier Dangles and Verónica Crespo-Pérez
For a complete overview see the Issue and the Editorial

ce:section.ce:para: Pests are animals that harm and destroy crops and forest products. In the imagination of most of the population (including scientists, farmers and stakeholders), many insects fall into this category because of their ability to feed on decayed and living plant tissues. Pest management practices have therefore flourished in order to control or eradicate them from our plantations and/or habitations [1]. This ‘dark’ side of insects is the subject of an exponentially growing body of literature that emerged in the 1990s. At the same time and in parallel with this school of thought, scientific literature is increasingly focusing on the importance of insects and their numerous threats on the numerous ecosystem services (ES) that they provide to humanity [2,3]. This ‘bright’ side of insects has been particularly evidenced by their role in pollination, although their impacts on the control of pests, nutrient cycling and carbon sequestration are increasing in popularity.

Termites are an interesting example of our dualistic appreciation of insect diversity. The dark side of termites is evidenced by an exponentially growing body of scientific studies aiming to control or eradicate them (Figure 1 ). Indeed, termite impacts can be very important in some situations and numerous articles reveal how termites can reduce the yield of many agricultural crops and forest products [4–7]. Therefore, to many, termites need to be eradicated to enable us to achieve our sustainable development goals (SDG) (e.g. providing food for humans and domestic animals, and reducing poverty by increasing farmers’ incomes). On the other hand, the bright side of termites is evidenced by scientific literature focusing on their role as ecosystem engineers or associated with the concept of sustainability. Although the ecological impact of termites was the subject of many works prior to the development of this concept [8], the concept of ‘ecosystem engineering’ continues to help underline the key role played by termites in modifying soil properties, landscape structure and the habitats of subordinate organisms [9]. Moreover, since termite biodiversity and activity are threatened by intensive agricultural practices, such as the conversion of natural forests to mono-plantations (e.g. [10,11]), their ecological impacts have mainly been evidenced in ‘more natural’ or protected environments. Therefore, it appears that ecologists and soil scientists have mainly focused on the beneficial impacts of termites in natural environments, without any apparent connection to their contribution to SDGs, while agronomists have mainly considered their role as pests in cultivated areas [5,12]. These two aspects constitute the framework of the present article. We argue that the time has come to unify these perceptions of termites in order to define new and more holistic appreciations of our cohabitation with termites and see the degree to which we can take advantage of their ecological impact to achieve SDGs [13].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Dilemma between harmful versus beneficial impacts
ce:section.ce:para: Termites are also part of food webs and contribute to the diet of many terrestrial animals [4]. Some species might even be specialized termite feeders, such as aardwolves (Proteles cristatus) in South Africa and the numbats (Myrmecobius fasciatus) in Australia [36,37]. The specific soil properties of termite constructions also offer valuable habitats for microbes [22] and plants [38], as well as shelter to predators, such as ants and snakes [26], which could be useful for controlling insects and rats in plantations and farms. Another consequence of this resource patchiness is that vegetation growing on mounds can represent foraging hotspots for herbivores (e.g. elephants, black rhinos and giraffes). From these examples, it appears that termite abundance and diversity are crucial drivers of ecosystem functioning and therefore must be considered in any strategy of ecological management or restoration.

Separate from all other topics in the bibliometric map shown in Figure 2 is all the research carried out on biotechnology and the study of the microbial properties within termite gut and termite mound soil [22,39,40]. Although at first glance the information gained from these studies is difficult to relate to SDGs, their outputs can be very practical and contribute to the emergence of new methods for the recycling of lignocellulosic substances, increasing the availability of phosphate in soil and the resistance of materials to natural degradation, and for curing diseases [7,41], in line with SDGs 3 and 9. Another interesting example is given by the utilization of termite mound soils for construction. The specific mechanical properties of termite mound soils make them interesting materials for construction and mixing this material with cement offers appropriate strength and plastic properties [4,22,33,42]. These characteristics are considered to be especially useful for low-income and medium-income earners in Africa. The shape and structure of termite mounds have also been very inspiring since termites are able to control the temperature and humidity within their mound nests by adapting their architecture to the environment. The mechanisms of this thermoregulation have long been described [43], and the nests remain cited as an example of biomimetic architecture for reducing the consumption of energy in buildings [44], thus contributing to SDG 11. Finally, the collective behaviour of termites has also been used as an inspired model for the creation of multi-agent construction robots that use just a few simple rules and environmental cues to build castle-like structures and pyramids.

Papers of particular interest, published within the period of review, have been highlighted as:
• of special interest
•• of outstanding interest

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: This review article is the outcome of a discussion initiated during the conference entitled ‘Insects: Friends, foes and models’ that was held at the French Academy of Sciences on March 12–14, 2019. Thanks are also extended to L. Ganesha for his unconditional support.

ce:section.ce:para: Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cois.2020.05.010.

ce:note.ce:simple-para: Kaiser et al. described the positive role played by termites in the traditional Zai cultural practice in West Africa. Together with [41], this study lays the foundation of an utilization of termites for the sustainable management of agrosystems.

ce:note.ce:simple-para: Miyagawa et al. describe the diversity of ecosystem services impacted by termite mounds in Asia. Although it focuses on termite mounds in Laos, qualitative information gained from this study is also valid in Thailand and in Cambodia.
